item.title: All failure is systems failure
item.description: It is common to blame or praise a person’s character for their current state. It is more useful for all involved to point out and redesign the systems that enabled that state.

item.title: Andy Matuschak
item.description: The creator of one of my favourite digital gardens of all time: Andy’s working notes. Created with Bear and a custom workflow of his creation, visible in this 2020-05-04 Note-writing livestream

item.title: Backlink
item.description: A link that allows you to go visit sources that link to the file you are currently looking at. This blog has a list of Backlinks at the bottom of every page.

item.title: Backlinks should include context
item.description: Backlinks are becoming increasingly popular in note taking applications, such as [[Obsidian]] and [[Notion]]. But sometimes these apps fail to supply context in their backlinks and thus make them worse to use.

item.title: Backups that work
item.description: You likely know what a backup is: a copy of something, stored away from the original. When the original is lost, the copy can fill its place.

item.title: Bear
item.description: A MacOS-only app for personal knowledge management. I used it for a short time, and like its aesthetic, but I prefer Obsidian and Logseq.

item.title: Berserk
item.description: ![[notes/images/berserk-banner.jpg]] One of the Big Three of [[Seinen]] [[Manga]], by Kentaro Miura. I first encountered the series in the early 2000s as a young teen, in its anime adaptation.

item.title: Blockquote
item.description: A long phrase or quotation that is embellished or highlighted as being especially important. They can function as an opportunity to show some typographic flair.

item.title: Data down, actions up
item.description: A rule or convention for making more maintainable component based web applications. The rule being, allow components to pass data such as text input to their children, and allow children to pass actions such as clicks to their parents.

item.title: Digital garden
item.description: A digital garden is a website, with content on multiple pages which link to each other. Differentiators from blogs A digital garden is very similar to a blog.

item.title: Elden Ring
item.description: Possibly my favourite videogame of 2022. Also the first [[Souls-like]] game I ever played. Why the game is fun It’s popular.

item.title: Ember CLI
item.description: A [[CLI]] tool for scaffolding EmberJS apps. Github Made by Stefan Penner Works on Windows but is slow because of NTFS.

item.title: EmberJS
item.description: A framework for making Single page apps. Popularised a UI engineering technique called data down, actions up. Why Ember over other frameworks like React, Vue, and Svelte?

item.title: Every productivity system stops working eventually
item.description: One of the most important things to know about productivity routines and systems is that none are invincible. GTD, Pomodoro, [[Animedoro]], Kanban, Agile, Pair Programming — all will eventually fail.

item.title: Feelings are not up for debate

item.description: ![[notes/images/Heros_Journey_diagram.jpg]] An extremely common trope, featuring a Hero character who is called to adventure, is victorious, and returns home changed.

item.title: Hieronymus Bosch
item.description: Netherlandish artist who painted Christian horror until his death in 1516 AD. There is an “official” website, and a project with high resolution scans, the Bosch project.

item.title: Hugo
item.description: A [[Static site generator]] built in [[Golang]]. Has a reputation for being incredibly fast, and feature rich. It also has a reputation for having terrible documentation.

item.title: Jurassic World: Dominion
item.description: The movie feels mostly like a chaotic carnival ride. You can expect some laughs and involuntary screams. That can be fun!

item.title: Knowledge workers toil roughly 20% more than they can comfortably handle
item.description: Since knowledge workers self regulate their workload, they default to a simple strategy: start saying “no” when they feel stressed.

item.title: My experience with Ubuntu in 2020
item.description: On 2020-November-10, I installed [[Ubuntu]] 18.04 on my computer. As of 2021-January-01, I’ve decided to retire it, though I did enjoy the experiment.

item.title: My favourite blogs and digital gardens
item.description: My personal notes are heavily inspired by the personal notes, blogs, and digital gardens of many others. The ones I love the most Andy’s working notes by Andy Matuschak is extremely enjoyable to read.

item.title: My note organisation system
item.description: I believe fervently that a good PKM system needs the following: A default place for new notes. When you want to write something down, you should not need to think about where to write, you should just write.

item.title: NIU KQI3 Scooter
item.description: Possibly the best value electric [[Scooter]] around. I discovered this scooter through Unbox Therapy and their video. A short while later I saw it on sale on Amazon for just $642USD including taxes and delivery, so I snapped it up.

item.title: Personal Knowledge Management
item.description: Personal Knowledge Management (PKM) is the skill of managing one’s life knowledge, secrets, and experiences so that they can be reused, relived, and built upon to create other work.

item.title: Punctuation
item.description: The characters between words, which convey meaning that words cannot. In English, they can include: [[Quotation marks]] such as “” [[Dashes]] such as — [[Mathematical operators]] such as × [[Foot and inch marks]] ′ It is common to approximate punctuation with a similar character because the real character is not available on the writer’s keyboard.

item.title: Quartz
item.description: A tool for publishing Obsidian to the web, and what I’m using for this note you’re reading now! It’s built on top of Hugo, which I’m told is very fast, but can be hard to use.

item.title: Radeon 6700 XT
item.description: An awesome GPU, released in 2021 on a 7nm process . I bought this to replace my ageing R9 285, a GPU released in 2014 on a 28nm process.

item.title: Search
item.description: Quartz supports two modes of searching through content. Full-text Full-text search is the default in Quartz. It produces results that exactly match the search query.

item.description: When you click a link on a website, you might see the screen turn white as you wait for the new page to be loaded.

item.description: A movie by Taika Waititi in the Marvel Cinematic Universe that you can probably skip. I’d recommend literally any other movie by Waititi, such as Jojo Rabbit.

item.title: Time timer
item.description: A physical timer, which operates on a single [[AA battery]]. Twisting the center knob resizes the coloured portion, which immediately starts shrinking as time progresses.

item.title: Trope
item.description: A storytelling tool, that has happened often enough to earn a name. Some tropes pander to a particular demographic. TV Tropes has more.

item.title: Typography
item.description: The art of arranging type to make written language legible and beautiful. Made up of some smaller skills including: [[Font selection]], particularly how to choose readable fonts for body and titles.

item.title: UI engineering
item.description: A branch of [[software engineering]], specialising in the creation of user interfaces to view and interact with data. A UI engineer may take a mostly complete [[UI design]] and convert it into a single page app, which connects to data from a back end.

item.title: Videogame
item.description: Videogames are a special kind of experience. They can be artistic, social. They can be aggravating and toxic. The first videogame I ever played was likely a Pac-Man rip-off when I was around 4 years old, on the family computer.

item.title: Why publish notes?
item.description: A few moments ago, my wife asked me “Why do you want to make a blog?”1 and my off the cuff answer was “Because I want to”.

item.title: You should link your notes
item.description: It is not the amount of knowledge that makes a brain. It is not even the distribution of knowledge. It is the interconnectedness.
